Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant is a Convention refugee due to statelessness or fear of persecution
Application_Facts: Applicant born in Russia, residing in Latvia, claims statelessness and discrimination in Latvia
Decision_Outcome: Applicant not recognized as a Convention refugee
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged statelessness and fear of persecution in Latvia
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution; eligibility under Convention refugee definition
Assessment_Factor: Ability to acquire Russian citizenship through simple process
Procedural_Issue: Panel review of refugee claim; Federal Court assessment of potential error
Evidence_Used: Evidence that applicant can obtain Russian citizenship by submitting application and passport for stamping
Application_Basis: Claim of statelessness and fear of persecution
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation regarding citizenship acquisition process in Russia
Relief_Sought: Grant of refugee status in Canada
Governing_Rule: A Convention refugee must have a well-founded fear of persecution and be outside country of nationality or lack one
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to demonstrate genuine inability to acquire Russian citizenship
Decisional_Body: Panel; Federal Court on judicial review
Cause_Description: Applicant claimed refugee status based on alleged statelessness and discrimination in Latvia
Evidence_Handling: Panel considered evidence of accessible Russian citizenship process
Residency_Compliance: Applicant resides in Latvia but born in Russia
Legal_Provision: Immigration Act - Definition of Convention refugee
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed applicant could easily acquire Russian citizenship
Decision_Rationale: Applicant is not stateless as she can readily obtain Russian citizenship; therefore does not meet refugee definition
Decision_Making_Body: Refugee status determination Panel; Federal Court (on review)
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution and lack of nationality or inability to avail protection of country of nationality
